pageDescription: Complete integration guide for Claude Code, Codex, and Droid CLI

navigation.tableOfContentsEmpty: No sections available on this page

codeExamples.label: Code example - ${language}
codeExamples.description: Click the code block to copy to clipboard

claudeCode.title: Claude Code Usage Guide
claudeCode.description: Claude Code is Anthropic's official AI programming assistant that supports integration through the cch proxy service. This guide will help you complete installation and configuration on different operating systems.

environmentSetup.title: Environment Setup: Install Node.js
environmentSetup.description: claude requires Node.js runtime (v18 or higher).

officialSteps: Download the LTS version for macOS (v18 or higher required)
Open the downloaded .pkg file and follow the installation wizard
Download the LTS version (v18 or higher required)
Double-click the .msi file and follow the installation wizard (keep default settings)
windows.note: It's recommended to use PowerShell instead of CMD for a better experience

verification.title: Verify Node.js Installation
verification.description: After installation, open terminal/command line and run the following commands to verify:
verification.success: If version numbers are displayed, the installation was successful!

nativeInstall.title: Native Install (recommended)
nativeInstall.description: Officially recommended installation method with the following advantages:
advantages: Single executable file, no Node.js dependency

macos.autoUpdateText: Claude Code installed via Homebrew will auto-update outside the brew directory unless explicitly disabled with the DISABLE_AUTOUPDATER environment variable.

linux.alpineText: Distributions based on musl/uClibc (such as Alpine Linux) need to install additional dependencies:

cmds: curl -fsSL https://claude.ai/install.cmd -o install.cmd && install.cmd && del install.cmd
curl -fsSL https://claude.ai/install.cmd -o install.cmd && install.cmd latest && del install.cmd
curl -fsSL https://claude.ai/install.cmd -o install.cmd && install.cmd 1.0.58 && del install.cmd

verification.title: Verify Installation
verification.description: After installation, run the following command to verify:
verification.success: If the version number is displayed, congratulations! Claude Code has been successfully installed.

nativeInstall.tipText: Before installation, make sure to remove any outdated aliases or symbolic links. Use the claude doctor command to check the installation type and version.

npmInstall.title: NPM
npmInstall.description: Using NPM installation requires Node.js 18 or higher first. Suitable for developers who prefer using NPM package manager.
npmInstall.warningText: Do NOT use sudo npm install -g, as this may cause permission issues and security risks. If you encounter permission errors, please refer to the NPM official solution.

verification.title: Verify Installation
verification.success: If the version number is displayed, congratulations! Claude Code has been successfully installed.

migration.title: Migrate to Native Install
migration.description: If you have already installed globally via NPM, you can use the following command to migrate to Native installation:
migration.note: Some users may be automatically migrated to this installation method.

verification.description: After configuration, verify that the environment variables are set correctly:

Create a config.json file in the ~/.claude directory (if it doesn't exist)

startup.initNote: During the first startup, claude will perform initial configuration.

commonIssues.title: Common questions
commandNotFoundWindows: Make sure the npm global path (usually C:\Users\your-username\AppData\Roaming\npm) has been added to the system PATH
commonIssues.commandNotFoundUnix: Check the npm global installation path and add it to PATH (if not already there)
commonIssues.updateNote: Re-run the installation script to update to the latest version.

codex.title: Codex CLI Usage Guide
codex.description: Codex is OpenAI's official command-line AI programming assistant that supports integration through the cch proxy. Note: Codex uses OpenAI-compatible format, the endpoint needs to include the /v1 path.

configFile.title: Configuration file setup
steps: Open file explorer, find the ${configPath} folder (create if it doesn't exist)
Create a config.toml file
Open with text editor and add the following content:
configFile.step4: Create an auth.json file and add:
importantPoints: Replace your-api-key-here with your cch API key
Note: Codex uses OpenAI-compatible format, endpoint includes the /v1 path

authJson.title: Config file method
authJson.configTomlDescription: Create config.toml file (when using auth.json to store the key, env_key field is not required):
authJson.noteText: This method stores the API key in auth.json file, no need to configure env_key field in config.toml.

envVars.title: Environment variable method
envVars.configTomlDescription: Create config.toml file (when using environment variables, env_key field is required):

windows.note: You need to reopen the PowerShell window for the settings to take effect.

vsCodeExtension.title: VS Code Extension Configuration
steps: Search for and install Codex – OpenAI's coding agent in VS Code extensions
Make sure you have configured config.toml and auth.json according to the steps above
Set the CCH_API_KEY environment variable
vsCodeExtension.importantText: env_key can only be an environment variable name (such as CCH_API_KEY), not the complete key. If you directly fill in the key, it will report an error that the token is not found or the token configuration is incorrect.

commonIssues.commandNotFoundUnix: Check the npm global installation path and add it to PATH (if not already there)

gemini.title: Gemini CLI Usage Guide
gemini.description: Gemini CLI is Google's official AI programming assistant command-line tool that supports integration through the cch proxy service. This guide will help you complete installation and configuration on different operating systems.

installation.title: Install gemini
installation.instruction: Make sure you have Node.js 18 or higher installed, then globally install Gemini CLI:

configFile.title: Method 1: Configuration File (Recommended)

step1.title: Create configuration directory
step1.description: Gemini CLI configuration files are located in the ~/.gemini/ directory.

step2.title: Create .env configuration file
step2.description: Create the .env file in the ~/.gemini/ directory:
step2.windowsInstruction: Windows: Create the .env file in the %USERPROFILE%\.gemini\ directory

step3.title: Create settings.json configuration file
step3.description: Create the settings.json file in the ~/.gemini/ directory:
step3.content: This configuration file enables IDE integration and sets the authentication method to API Key.

parameters: GEMINI_API_KEY: Your API key created in the cch console
GEMINI_MODEL: Model to use (default is gemini-2.5-pro)
importantPoints: Replace YOUR_API_KEY_HERE with your actual API key
How to obtain the key: Log in to the console → API Key Management → Create Key

envVars.title: Method 2: Environment Variable Configuration
envVars.description: If you only want to use it temporarily, you can configure it via environment variables:

macosLinux.title: macOS / Linux:
macosLinux.note: Environment variables are only valid for the current terminal session. For persistent configuration, use the configuration file method.

windows.note: Environment variables are only valid for the current terminal session. For persistent configuration, use the configuration file method.

startCli.title: Start Gemini CLI
startCli.description: Navigate to your project directory and start Gemini CLI:
startCli.note: On first startup, Gemini CLI will read the settings in the configuration file.

verification.title: Verify Configuration
verification.description: Try sending a simple request in Gemini CLI to test the connection:
verification.testCommand: Hello, please help me create a Python hello world program
verification.success: If Gemini CLI responds normally, the configuration is successful!

agentMode.title: Using Agent Mode
agentMode.description: Gemini CLI supports Agent Mode, which can automatically plan and execute complex tasks:
featureList: Execute step by step and verify results

commonIssues.title: Common Issues
commandNotFoundWindows: Make sure the npm global path (usually C:\Users\your-username\AppData\Roaming\npm) has been added to the system PATH
commonIssues.commandNotFoundUnix: Check the npm global installation path and add it to PATH (if not already there)
connectionSteps: Check if GEMINI_API_KEY in the environment variables or configuration file is set correctly

opencode.title: OpenCode Usage Guide
opencode.description: OpenCode is a CLI + TUI AI coding agent that runs in your terminal and also provides IDE integrations. You can point OpenCode to cch as a single entry to access Claude, GPT, and Gemini models.

macos.description: On macOS, install OpenCode using one of the following methods:

linux.description: On Linux, install OpenCode using one of the following methods:

script.title: Option 1: Official install script
script.description: Run the following command to install the latest version:

npm.title: Option 3: npm
npm.note: Note: Avoid installing opencode-ai via npm mirror registries. Mirror registries may cause missing dependencies; use the official npm registry if you hit issues.

windows.description: On Windows, we recommend a package manager (Chocolatey/Scoop); npm also works:

scoop.title: Option 2: Scoop
scoop.command:
scoop bucket add extras
scoop install extras/opencode

windows.note: Note: Bun on Windows is still in progress. Use Chocolatey/Scoop/npm, or download a binary from GitHub Releases.

configFile.title: Configure opencode.json
configFile.instruction: Edit the file and add the following content (one file covers all models):
importantPoints: Create an API key in the cch console and set the CCH_API_KEY environment variable
When selecting models, use provider_id/model_id (e.g. openai/gpt-5.2 or cchClaude/claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929)

modelSelection.title: Select a model
modelSelection.description: After starting OpenCode, use the following command in the TUI to view/select models:

startup.title: Start opencode
startup.initNote: On first launch, opencode loads the config and creates a session.

commonIssues.title: Common issues
commandNotFoundWindows: If installed via npm, make sure your global npm bin directory is on PATH
Open a new terminal and try again
commonIssues.commandNotFoundUnix: Check the install location and add it to PATH (e.g. ~/.local/bin or npm global bin)

droid.title: Droid CLI Usage Guide
droid.description: Droid is an interactive terminal AI programming assistant developed by Factory AI that supports integration through the cch proxy service. You must register and log in to your Droid official account before use.

linux.note: Linux users need to ensure xdg-utils is installed:

configuration.title: Connect to cch service
configuration.prerequisite: Prerequisite: Must log in to Droid official account first
prerequisiteSteps: Follow the prompts to log in to Factory official account via browser
After successful login, you can continue to configure custom models

customModels.title: Configure custom models
customModels.instruction: Edit the configuration file and add the following content:
importantPoints: Replace your-api-key-here with your cch API key

switching.title: Switch models
steps: Restart Droid
Enter the /model command
Select GPT-5-Codex [cch] or Sonnet 4.5 [cch]
Start using!

startup.title: Start droid
startup.description: Run the following command in your project directory:
startup.initNote: During the first startup, droid will perform initial configuration.

commonIssues.commandNotFoundUnix: Check the npm global installation path and add it to PATH (if not already there)

commonCommands.title: Common commands
commonCommands.description: After starting Claude Code, you can use the following common commands:

commands.description: Clear chat history and start a new conversation
View the amount spent in the current conversation

commonCommands.moreCommands: For more commands, see the official documentation

installationFailed.title: Installation failed
steps: Check if network connection is normal
Make sure you have administrator privileges (Windows) or use sudo (macOS / Linux)
Try using a proxy or mirror source (npm can use the --registry parameter)

invalidApiKey.title: API key is invalid
steps: Confirm the key has been copied correctly (no extra spaces)
Check if the key is within the validity period
Verify that account permissions are normal
Confirm the correct endpoint format is used (Anthropic no /v1, OpenAI has /v1)

endpointConfigError.title: Endpoint configuration error
points: Claude Code / Droid Anthropic model: Use ${resolvedOrigin} (no /v1)
Codex / Droid OpenAI model: Use ${resolvedOrigin}/v1 (must include /v1)
